item.label: Cerebral lobes
item.name: Cerebral lobes -- arrows
item.description: Each cerebral hemisphere consists of lobes:  frontal, parietal, occipital, temporal.  In some instances a limbic lobe is designated-- consisting of a portion of the medial aspect of the other lobes.

item.label: Occipital
item.name: Occipital -- arrows
item.description: The occipital lobe is the most posterior lobe of the cerebral hemispheres. It is clinically important because it includes the primary and association visual cortex.

item.label: Temporal
item.name: Temporal -- arrows
item.description: The temporal lobe is the most inferior lobe of the cerebral hemispheres.  It is located below the lateral sulcus and anterior to the occipital lobe. Important structures within the temporal lobe include: auditory sensory and association cortex, part of the posterior language cortex, visual and higher-order association cortex, primary and association olfactory cortex, amygdala, hippocampus and the inferior or temporal horn of the lateral ventricle.

item.label: Pons
item.name: Pons
item.description: The pons is that portion of the brainstem between the midbrain and medulla. It consists of a basilar or basal portion that contains structures primarily associated with motor control and a tegmental portion that contains cranial nerve nuclei and important sensory tracts. The cerebellum overlies the pons and medulla. The rostral aspect of the fourth ventricle is located on the dorsal surface of the pons. The pons and cerebellum originate embryologically from the metencephalon of the hindbrain.

item.label: Tegmentum
item.name: Tegmentum
item.description: The tegmentum or tegmental pons forms the dorsal aspect of the pons.  It is continuous with the tegmental portions of both the midbrain and medulla. Includes cranial nerve nuclei and clinically important sensory tracts [medial lemniscal, spinothalamic, lateral lemniscal]. The rostral aspect of the fourth ventricle is located on it dorsal surface.

item.label: Basilar
item.name: Basilar
item.description: The basilar pons is AKA the basal pons. It is the ventral portion of the pons that includes the following important elements that are primarily involved in motor control: corticospinal, corticobulbar, corticospinal and pontocerebellar tracts plus the pontine nuclei. Thus, it serves as a conduit for descending motor pathways from cerebral cortex to the pons, medulla and spinal cord. In addition, it connects the cerebral cortex with the cerebellum via synapses of the corticopontine fibers on pontine nuclei that then give origin to the pontocerebellar fibers which terminate in cerebellum.

item.label: Trigeminal nerves
item.name: Trigeminal nerves
item.description: The fifth or trigeminal cranial nerve enters/exits the brain stem through the basilar portion of the pons. It provides somatosensory innervation to the head via its ophthalmic, maxillary and mandibular roots which converge upon the trigeminal ganglion and then form a massive sensory root entering the brainstem. It provides motor innervation to the muscles derived from the first branchial arch (muscles of mastication, tensor tympani, anterior belly of diagastric, tensor veli palatini and mylohyoid) via a smaller motor root that distributes with the mandibular sensory root.

item.label: Cerebellum
item.name: Cerebellum
item.description: The cerebellum is sometimes referred to as the 'small' brain.  It is located within the posterior fossa, superior to the brain stem. It consists of a finely convoluted cortical surface of folia, a central core of white matter (AKA medullary center) and four paired deep nuclei (dentate, emboliform, fastigial and globose) embedded within the white matter core. The cerebellum functions in the planning and coordination of movement.

item.label: Hemispheres
item.name: Hemispheres
item.description: The cerebellar hemispheres are the largest portion of the cerebellum located on either side of the midline vermis. They are functionally important relative to coordination of the limbs.

item.label: Vermis
item.name: Vermis
item.description: The vermis of the cerebellum is the most medial region, i.e. the narrow midline section associated with the anterior, posterior and flocculonodular lobes of the cerebellum.

item.label: Middle cerebellar peduncles
item.name: Middle cerebellar peduncles
item.description: The middle cerebellar peduncle consists exclusively of pontocerebellar tract fibers that take their origin from pontine nuclei in the contralateral basilar pons. Thus, it carries afferent information to cerebellum from the contralateral cerebral cortex via the corticopontine to pontine nuclei to pontocerebellar tract.

item.label: Arteries, branches of
item.name: Arteries_branches of
item.description: The arterial supply to the brain is via the paired internal carotid and vertebral arteries. The terminal branches of the internal carotid arteries are the paired anterior and middle cerebral arteries which supply supratentorial structures.  The two vertebral arteries enter the cranial cavity via the foramen magnum; they join one another at the junction of the medulla with the pons to form the basilar artery.  Together the vertebral-basilar system of arteries supplies the structures of the posterior fossa as well as those supratentorial structures supplied by its terminal branches -- the posterior cerebral arteries.

item.label: Internal carotid
item.name: Internal carotid
item.description: With the verbebral arteries, the internal carotid arteries provide the blood supply to the brain. The internal carotid branches from the common carotid in the neck and enters the base of the skull via the carotid canal. As it enters the Circle of Willis, it divides into its two terminal branches: the middle and anterior cerebral arteries.

item.label: Basilar
item.name: Basilar_1
item.description: The two vertebral arteries fuse at the junction of the medulla and pons to form the basilar artery. At the junction of the pons and midbrain, the basilar bifurcates into two terminal branches, the posterior cerebral arteries. Branches of the basilar & posterior cerebral arteries supply parts of the brain stem, cerebellum, posterior aspects of the diencephalon, choroid plexus in the third and lateral ventricles and the medial and inferior surfaces of the occipital and temporal lobes of the cerebral hemispheres.

item.label: Dural venous sinuses
item.name: Dural venous sinuses
item.description: The dural venous sinuses are endothelial-lined spaces between the periosteal and meningeal layers of the dura.  They form where the meningeal layer of the dura is reflected away from the surface of the skull and into the spaces between parts of the brain such as the longitudinal fissure.  Included are the superior sagittal, inferior sagittal, straight, transverse, occipital, sigmoid, cavernous, superior petrosal, and inferior petrosal sinuses.  Most of the blood from the brain empties into these sinuses before draining into the internal jugular veins and leaving the cranium.

item.label: Cavernous sinuses
item.name: Cavernous sinuses
item.description: The cavernous sinuses are located on either side of the sella turcica on the upper part of the sphenoid bone.  They consist of a venous plexus of thin-walled, interconnected veins.  There is communication between the two cavernous sinuses via the intercavernous sinuses.  Many functionally-important structures pass through the cavernous sinuses including the internal carotid artery, cranial nerves III, IV, V and VI.

item.label: Basilar plexus
item.name: Basilar plexus
item.description: The basilar venous plexus consists of several plexiform venous channels between the layers of the dura over the basilar part of the occipital bone.  It connects the inferior petrosal dural venous sinuses of the two sides and communicates with the internal vertebral venous plexus.

item.label: Confluence
item.name: Confluence
item.description: The confluence of the dural sinuses is the convergence point of the superior sagittal, straight, occipital and transverse sinuses near the occipital protuberance.

item.label: Transverse
item.name: Transverse
item.description: The transverse dural venous sinuses pass laterally from the confluence of the sinuses at the occipital protuberance. They travel along the posterolateral attached margins of the cerebellar tentorium and empty into or become the sigmoid sinuses as they approach the petrous portion of the temporal bone.  Often the left transverse sinus is larger than its counterpart of the right.

item.label: Ventricular system, Fourth ventricle
item.name: Ventricular system Fourth ventricle
item.description: The fourth ventricle is a rhomboid-shaped space located superior to the pons and medulla. The roof of the fourth ventricle is formed by the inferior and superior medullary vela plus the cerebellum. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) enters the fourth ventricle from the third ventricle via the cerebral aqueduct. CSF exits the fourth ventricle into the subarachnoid space via the medial foramen of Magendie, located in the roof of the fourth ventricle, and the two lateral foramina of Luschka, located at the most lateral aspect of the fourth ventricle, i.e. in the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle, bilaterally.  The choroid plexus is located in the roof of the fourth ventricle, beneath the inferior medullary velum.  The choroid plexus extends outside of the fourth ventricle through the foramina of Luschka, where it can be visualized in the subarachnoid space.

item.label: Bony & other features
item.name: Bony_other features
item.description: Portions of the bone of the neurocranium (cranial vault or brain case) and the viscerocranium (facial skeleton) are often seen in images of the brain.  In some instances, they are intimately involved with the dura, dural venous sinuses, formation of the paranasal air sinuses, etc.

item.label: Nasal septum
item.name: Nasal septum
item.description: The nasal cavity is divided into right and left halves by the nasal septum.  It is composed of the septal cartilage, the vomer, the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid bone, the maxillary crest and the premaxilla.

item.label: Air sinuses
item.name: Air sinuses
item.description: The air or paranasal sinuses are extensions of the respiratory part of the nasal cavity that extend into the cranial bones:  frontal, ethmoid, sphenoid and maxillary.

item.label: Ethmoidal
item.name: Ethmoidal
item.description: The ethmoidal air sinuses (or cells) are small invaginations of the mucous membrane of the middle and superior nasal meatus into the ethmoid bone between the nasal cavity and orbit.  Usually not visible on plain radiographs before age 2 but detectable on CT scans.  The anterior and middle ethmoidal cells drain into the middle nasal meatus while the posterior ethmoidal cells drain into the superiror meatus.

item.label: Maxillary
item.name: Maxillary
item.description: The maxillary sinuses are the largest of the paranasal air sinuses.  They are located within the maxillae and drain into the middle nasal meatus.

item.label: Sphenoidal
item.name: Sphenoidal
item.description: The sphenoidal air sinuses are located in the body of the sphenoid bone and may extend into the wings of this bone.  They are unevenly divided and separated by a bony septum.  Very thin plates of bone separate these fragile sinuses from many important structures:  the optic nerves and chiasm, the pituitary gland, the internal carotid arteries and the cavernous sinuses.

item.label: Petrous temporal bone
item.name: Petrous temporal bone
item.description: The petrous portion of the temporal bone presents a very complex shape and surface.  It is located at the base of the skull between the sphenoid and occipital bones.  The cochlear and vestibular organs are contained within this bone.
